net.ognyanov.niogram.util

Class BitSetLLString

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.ognyanov.niogram.util.BitSetLLString
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Cloneable, Iterable<BiasedBitSet>

    public final class BitSetLLString
extends Object
implements Cloneable, Serializable, Iterable<BiasedBitSet>
    A limited length string of bitsets. Used to represent linearized FirstKL/FollowKL "sets". In these strings the terminal sets at each position contain all the terminals (and only the terminals) which occur at the same position in some string of the corresponding FirstK/FollowK set.

    From mathematical standpoint the FirstK and the FollowK sets are solutions to some systems of functional equations. The operations on strings of sets are defined so as to be isomorphic to the operations on sets of strings used in those systems of equations. Implementation details of individual operations are described in the methods documentation. The main implementation idea is to associate with every string of sets a list of string lengths which appear in an isomorphic set of strings.

    Author:
    Nikolay Ognyanov
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

        public Set<Integer> stringLengths()

        Returns:

      • isEmpty

        public boolean isEmpty()
        Tests whether the object is empty. This means that that the both the underlying sequence of BiasedBitSet and the set of string lengths are empty. If the sequence of BiasedBitSet is empty the set of string lengths may still contain the zero length which simulates the presence of an empty string in a "dual" IntLLStringSet.
        Returns:
        the result of the test

      • isFull

        public boolean isFull()
        Tests whether the current length of the string is equal to its limit.
        Returns:
        true if the length is equal to the limit; false otherwise

      • add

        public void add(BiasedBitSet... bitSets)
        Appends copies of argument BiasedBitSets at the beginning of the string. The length of the argument sequence is added to the set of string lengths of this object. Adding a zero-length argument sequence is treated as an addition of an empty string to the pseudo "set". Thus the method is isomorphic to LLStringSet.add(IntLLString)}. In practice this does not matter because the NioGram core code only uses this method to initialize the firstKL/followKL fields content of terminal rules with a single bitset containing a single terminal symbol.
        Parameters:
        bitSets - the sequence of bitsets to be added.

      • addAll

        public void addAll(BitSetLLString other)
        Adds the elements of the other string at the beginning of this string. Adds all string lengths of the other string to the set of lengths of this one.
        Parameters:
        other - the string to be added to this

      • append

        public void append(BitSetLLString other)
        Adds the other string at all positions in the set of string lengths of this string. Then creates a new list of string lengths which consists of all sums of a string length from this string and a string length from the other string.
        Parameters:
        other - the string to be appended to this one

      • get

        public BiasedBitSet get(int position)
        Retrieves the BiasedBitSet at given position in the string. Throws IndexOutOfBoundsException if the specified position is invalid.
        Parameters:
        position - the position
        Returns:
        the bitset at the specified position

                          int value)

        true if the test succeeds; false otherwise

      • containsAll

        public boolean containsAll(BitSetLLString other)
        Tests that the argument string satisfies the following:
        1. The string lengths of the argument are a subset of the string lengths of this object.
        2. The set at each position in the argument is a subset of the set at the same position in this object.
        Parameters:
        other - the string to be tested
        Returns:
        true if the tests pass; false otherwise

      • matches

        public boolean matches(IntLLString intLLString)
        Tests whether an argument string is matched by this object. A match is defined as the integer at every position in the argument being contained in the set at the same position in this object.
        Parameters:
        intLLString - the string to be tested
        Returns:
        true if the argument is matched; false otherwise
